awd_titl_txt: Modulation of Bubble-Mediated Gas Transfer due to Wave-Current Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This is project will study the spatial variability of gas transfer across the air-sea interface within a comprehensive modeling framework. Theoretical and modeling studies agree at relatively small scales, where the flow becomes less dominated by the rotation of the earth, motion, especially along the vertical direction becomes more energetic, with pronounced impacts on ocean biogeochemistry, and air-sea fluxes. However, no study has focused on wave breaking variability and related bubble mediate gas transfer due to wave-current interactions. Most parameterizations of gas transfer coefficients today depend on wind speed rather than more detailed representation of wave dynamics, resulting in large uncertainties. Recent parameterizations include wave effects through integral wave parameters such as significant wave height or wave age, neither which can explain the modulation due to wave-current interactions at sharp fronts.  A recently developed model of wave breaking statistics provides a framework to explicitly account for breaking on air entrainment and bubble-mediated gas fluxes. The model is suitable for coupled earth system simulations providing a unique opportunity to study the effect of wave-current interactions on the variability of bubble-mediated gas transfer and fluxes. The results will have direct applications for climate studies. They can explain the uncertainty of the observed gas fluxes in coastal environments, helping to reduce the uncertainty of global CO2 budgets. Other impacts include training students. Specifically, an undergraduate student will participate in the research. The project will enhance the participation of underrepresented groups by contributing to the career of a Hispanic, early-career scientist, and by exposing the students at UCSB, a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution, to the research and its results. 

The overarching goal of the work is to investigate the modulation of bubble-mediated gas transfer due to wave-current interactions at submesoscales. The modeling is based on recent advances on surface wave breaking and related air-sea fluxes, which provide a physics-based framework to model bubble-mediated gas transfer coefficients. Realistic numerical simulations will be used to investigate the spatial variability of bubble-mediated gas transfer and their impact on gas fluxes (i.e., CO2). Preliminary model results show that wave breaking statistics forced by realistic winds and currents confirm previous findings from observations and theoretical analysis on the modulation of waves by currents, where wave breaking is enhanced in conditions with winds obliquely aligned with ocean fronts. The wave breaking modulation by currents is enhanced with increasing model resolution at submesoscales. Submesoscale frontal surface convergence and downwelling velocities overlap with areas with enhanced wave breaking with oblique wind forcing. It is hypothesized that under these conditions air-sea gas fluxes are enhanced. This will be tested with numerical simulations at an eastern boundary current during upwelling conditions. Upwelling areas have been shown to exhibit significant variability in CO2 concentrations that is not well understood. Dissolved CO2 will be modeled neglecting biological and chemical reactions starting from a background equilibrium level and then forced with realistic fluxes, including bubble-mediated transfer coefficients. The hypothesis will be tested by comparing model solutions at varying resolutions against a control run using standard transfer coefficient parameterizations that depend only on wind speed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ocean surface waves play a crucial role in influencing gas transfer across the air-sea interface. However, gas transfer is commonly parameterized only as a function of wind speed not explicitly accounting for the sea state. Air-sea gas transfer is driven by two processes molecular diffusion enhanced by turbulence and bubbles generated by breaking waves, with the latter being more important in high winds. Based on recent physics-based advances in the modeling of CO2 air-sea exchanges due to bubbles combined with a recent model of wave-breaking statistics, this study investigated the impact of wave-current interactions on wave-breaking and CO2 air-sea transfer. Realistic high-resolution numerical experiments showed that the modulation of the surface gravity waves by submesoscale currents is most significant for the short waves and wave breaking. For example, the significant wave height which is often used to characterize the sea state is only weakly modulated at submesoscales by about 12%, whereas the whitecap coverage can vary by 50% or more. The modulation of short gravity waves resulting from surface convergence and horizontal shear along submesoscale fronts and filaments markedly amplifies wave-breaking and CO2 transfer coefficients due to bubbles. The obtained variability in CO2 transfer rates, approximately 50%, due to wave-current interactions is within the variability observed in field measurements. Further numerical experiments, involving passive CO2, indicate that the enhanced transfer rates along fronts and filaments do not impact the net CO2 uptake or efflux. Notably, these findings are based on model solutions with horizontal resolutions down to 400 m, without accounting for feedback, specifically wave effects on currents. It is conceivable that at even higher resolutions, increased submesoscale vertical velocities in the upper ocean could lead to amplified CO2 uptake or efflux rates in regions with persistent submesoscale activity and wave-current interactions. Additionally, wave effects on currents at submesoscales can either augment frontal circulation or degrade fronts due to wave-induced vertical mixing, both of which can influence air-sea gas exchange.

As the global atmospheric CO2 concentration continues to rise, it is crucial to enhance our understanding of the processes governing air-sea fluxes. The insights gained from this study can play a vital role in reducing the uncertainty associated with CO2 fluxes and refining CO2 budgets, directly benefiting climate and biogeochemical modeling. Additionally, this project has made significant contributions to the enhancement of sea state-based parametrizations for CO2 air-sea transfer, making them more suitable for global models. This project provided research opportunities for three undergraduate students, one graduate student (Bernard Akaawase), and one postdoctoral (Youngmi Shin) scholar. One side project led by undergraduate researcher Kabir Lubana characterized the performance of numerical wave models in terms of the spectral shape and showed for the first time that it is now possible to accurately predict the directional distribution of the energy spectrum over a wide range of scales providing a pathway to predict microseisms at scales below 2 Hz.
